title: 105_s2545
content: The "Medicare HMO Protection Act of 1998" allows for the evaluation and alteration of termination decisions. The Social Security Act allows the Secretary to delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice plan if it poses a serious health risk, reduces plan availability, or if the terminating organization is not offering coverage. The Secretary may delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice plan if it poses a serious health risk, reduces plan availability, or if the terminating organization is not offering coverage. The Secretary can end the delay if an adequate provider network is established. The Secretary can delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice plan if it poses health risks or reduces plan availability. An adequate provider network must be established to ensure equal insurance coverage for beneficiaries. If the termination is delayed, negotiations for a new contract can take place to continue coverage without adversely affecting beneficiaries. The Social Security Act is amended to extend the initial Medicare+Choice contract period to 3 years. This change applies to contracts entered into after the enactment of the Act. The Social Security Act is amended to require Medicare+Choice organizations to provide written notice 120 days before terminating a contract, including information on alternative plans and policies available in the area. The Social Security Act amendment mandates Medicare+Choice organizations to give 120-day written notice before contract termination, including details on available alternative plans and local social service agency contact information for Medicare beneficiaries. The amendment applies to termination notices issued after the Act's enactment date.
